div.p:
It would have given you pleasure to have
been present when Harriet brought to my
bed's foot this morning vos depêches and
Karamania.

I laid aside your letter
and Hunters half read to examine your
publication. I think the book extremely ele-
-gant elegant , beautifully printed and adorned
with engravings executed with uncommon
neatness and effect. We dipped into the book
- I like the style - And I augur well of its success.

With respect to your transactions
with Hunter - nothing could be more ef-
-fective effective or more ably managed. And we
all of us consider your account of this tran-
saction transaction to be as clear and comprehensive
as language could permit.

I send you a copy of my letter to
Hunter to save you some postage - But I am
ruining you in postage and coach-hire.

Adieu my dear Brother - If any
thing could make Fanny dearer to me than
her own merit, it would be the having
such a brother as you
